abstracts.cdata!:
The project is rated as marginally
            unsatisfactory in its outcome, and unlikly to be sustained.
            Overall Bank performance is rated as satisfactory, despite
            the drop in supervision intensity during the latter years of
            project execution, when the focus was on attempts to use
            unspent balances of project resources. On the whole,
            Borrower performance was satisfactory. Six lessons were
            learned from this project: On a strategic level, a project
            seeking to invest in techncial capacity needs to ensure that
            government staff skills, education, management systems and
            equipment are underpinned by institutional arrangements
            capable of creating incentives and rules to effectively
            harness the fruits of such investments. Second the
            traditional multi-component technical assistance projects
            with multiple executing agencies addressing a core
            government function should include only those components
            that are closely interdependent. Third an unmanageable
            component of a third should be dropped and freed up
            resources shifted to components that are implementing well.
            Fourth the implications of the technical complexity of
            computerized information systems should not be
            underestimated. Fifth excessive staff turnover compromised
            the continuity and purposefulness of project execution.
            Sixth, proper planning and arrangements should be made to
            ensure that counterparts are made available to work
            alongside external consultants, and that they are given
            incentives to stay committed for the duration of the projec
